1   Introduction¶

This document describes the Intermediate Service Model format of the Language Ecosystem for Modeling Microservice Archictecture. The project aims to facilitate the development of microservice-based software systems [New15] by employing Model-driven Development (MDD) [CFJezequel+17].

In this context, a microservice architecture consists of several different types of models, listed in Table 1.

Table 1 Model types¶
Model Type Description
Domain Data Model A Domain Data Model describes the domain-specific data used by a modeled microservice to specify its input/output data. See also the Intermediate Data Model Format Specification.
Mapping Model A Mapping Model allows for assigning (alternative) technologies to, e.g., modeled microservices in a Service Model and complex types in a Data Model.
Service Model A Service Model contains several microservice models, their interfaces, and operations. The contents of imported Domain Data Models, e.g., data structures, may be used to type operations’ parameters.
Operation Model An Operation Model expresses the deployment of microservices being imported from Service Models.
Technology Model A Technology models encapsulates descriptions of technologies. For instance, certain implementation technologies, e.g., Java or Go, and protocol technologies, e.g., REST or AMQP, may be contained in a Technology Model. Moreover, service or operation aspects [KLM+97] may be defined, which enable to reify technology specifications in Mapping, Operation, or Service Models.

2   Model Processing¶

The creation of the models happens within a bundle of Eclipse [1] plugins that are based on Xcore [2] and Xtext [3]. These technologies build upon the Ecore metamodeling standard [SBPM11] and the Eclipse Modeling Framework (EMF) [4].

However, to detach the processing of the models from the Eclipse ecosystem and allow microservice teams for creating custom model processors like validators and code generators [CFJezequel+17] that do not need to depend on EMF, the models are exported [5] from Eclipse to the technology-agnostic XML Metadata Interchange (XMI) format [6].

XMI is based on XML and encodes a model instance, whose metamodel [CFJezequel+17] is based on the Meta Object Facility (MOF) [7] which is generally the case for Ecore metamodels and derived model instances.

3   Format Specification¶

This document describes the metamodel and thus the structure of XMI files of Intermediate Service Models, i.e., instances of Domain Data Models that were exported from Eclipse (cf. 1   Introduction and 2   Model Processing). It may be used as reference, when implementing custom model processors for microservice-related Service Models.

Fig. 1 shows the structure of the metamodel of the Intermediate Service Models in an object-oriented way in the form of a UML class diagram. The modeling concepts, their properties, and relationships are depicted as classes, attributes, and associations, respectively.

Fig. 1 Metamodel of Intermediate Service Models

In the following, the document contains a reference of each modeling concept of the metamodel depicted in Fig. 1.

Hint

Attributes that may contain more than one value but exhibit a * multiplicity, i.e., they may contain an arbitrary number of values or even none at all (* is shorthand UML notation for 0..*), are never null.

In case no multiplicity is stated after the object type of an attribute, the attribute may be null. For example, an attribute defined as String name implicitly has a multiplicity 0..1 and in the zero-case the String may be null.

However, in case the attribute’s type is a built-in primitive Java type, e.g. int, the attribute will never be null but exhibits the type’s default value in case it did not receive an explicit value.

3.1   Model Root¶

class IntermediateServiceModel¶

Root of the Intermediate Service Model instance.

String[1] sourceModelUri

“file” URI pointing to the source Service Model file from which this model was derived. Not that this might be an empty string, if the IntermediateMicroservice instances were derived from different Service Models. Model processors should then rely on the eponymous attribute in the IntermediateMicroservice concept.

IntermediateImport[*] imports

References to IntermediateDataModel, Technology Model (cf. Table 1), or Intermediate Service Model instances that were imported into the source Service Model (cf. IntermediateImport).

IntermediateMicroservice[1..*] microservices

Modeled microservices in the source Service Model.

3.2   Microservices¶

class IntermediateMicroservice¶

A modeled microservice.

String[1] sourceModelUri

“file” URI pointing to the source Service Model file from which this microservice originates.

String[1] name

Unique name of the service.

String version

Optional version of the service.

String[1] qualifiedName

Qualified name of the service. This is the service’s name prefixed by its version, if any. Both name fragments are separated by dots.

MicroserviceType[1] type

Type of the microservice.

Visibility[1] visibility

Visibility of the microservice.

boolean effectivelyImplemented

Flag to indicate if the microservice has at least one IntermediateOperation that is not marked as being not not implemented (either directly or transitively via its encapsulating IntermediateInterface.

Hint

Code generators should consider to also generate code for not (yet) implemented microservices and, e.g., return failures to callers.

IntermediateTechnology[*] technologies

Technologies assigned to the microservice.

Note

In case, no technologies are specified for a microservice, code generators are free to generate code for the microservice or not.

Hint

There can only be one technology that defines default primitive types. Moreover, it is guaranteed that default protocol/data format combinations are unambiguous. For instance, there can only be one default synchronous protocol across all referenced technologies.

IntermediateEndpoint[*] endpoints

Endpoints assigned to the microservice.

Hint

If no endpoints were specified for the microservice’s (default) protocol specifications, the addresses attribute of the IntermediateEndpoint class will be empty.

If no endpoints were specified or could be determined from (default) protocol specifications, or in case the addresses attribute is empty, code generators should produce sensible defaults, e.g., from the microservice’s name.

IntermediateProtocolSpecification[0..2] protocols

Protocol specifications assigned to the microservice. There might be exactly one protocol specification per communication type.

Note

In case the microservice had no protocols assigned in the source Service Model, the default protocols of the missing communication types are taken from the assigned technologies. That is, the attribute is only empty if the microservice had no protocol-defining technology assigned.

Hint

If no protocol specifications are assigned to the service, code generators should produce sensible defaults, e.g., from the microservice’s name.

MicroserviceReference[*] requiredMicroservices

References to required microservices.

InterfaceReference[*] requiredInterfaces

References to required interfaces.

OperationReference[*] requiredOperations

References to required operations.

IntermediateImportedAspect[*] aspects

Aspects of the microservice.

IntermediateServiceModel serviceModel

Link to the containing IntermediateServiceModel instance.

enum MicroserviceType¶

Possible types of an IntermediateMicroservice.

enumerator FUNCTIONAL¶

A functional microservice realizes the business functions of the microservice-based software system.

enumerator INFRASTRUCTURE¶

Infrastructure microservices provide the architecture with capabilities that are not related to business but technical functions. Examples of such functions comprise database lookups or integration of legacy systems.

enumerator UTILITY¶

Teams may realize utility microservices to implement reusable, business-related helper functions, e.g., for currency conversion.

enum Visibility¶

Possible visibilitiy qualifiers of an IntermediateMicroservice, IntermediateInterface, and IntermediateOperation.

enumerator INTERNAL¶

Internal services/interfaces/operations must only be visible to the services of the same team.

enumerator IN_MODEL¶

Qualifies an interface/operation to be visible only within the current service model file and its services.

enumerator ARCHITECTURE¶

Architecture services/interfaces/operations must only be visible to the services of the same architecture, but not to external consumers.

enumerator PUBLIC¶

Public services/interfaces/operations must be visible to all services of the same architecture and also to external consumers.

class IntermediateInterface¶

This class represents an interface of an IntermediateMicroservice.

String[1] name

Name of the interface.

String version

Optional version of the interface.

String[1] qualifiedName

Qualified name of the interface. This is the interface’s name prefixed by its version and its microservice’s qualified name. All name fragments are separated by dots.

Visibility[1] visibility

Visibility of the interface.

boolean notImplemented

Flag to indicate if the interface was marked as being not implemented.

Hint

Code generators should consider to also generate code for not (yet) implemented interfaces and, e.g., return failures to callers.

boolean hasImplementedOperations

Flag to indicate if the interface has at least one operation whose notImplemented attribute is false.

Hint

Code generators should consider to also generate code for interfaces whose operations are not (yet) implemented and, e.g., return failures to callers.

Note

The notImplemented and hasImplementedOperations are independent of each other. The first is set by the modeler, while the second is derived from the corresponding flags of the interface’s operations.

IntermediateEndpoint[*] endpoints

Endpoints assigned to the interface.

Hint

If no endpoints were specified for the interface’s (default) protocol specifications, the addresses attribute of the IntermediateEndpoint class will be empty.

If no endpoints were specified or could be determined from (default) protocol specifications, or in case the addresses attribute is empty, code generators should produce sensible defaults, e.g., from the interface’s name.

IntermediateProtocolSpecification[0..2] protocols

Protocol specifications assigned to the interface. There might be exactly one protocol specification per communication type.

Hint

If no protocol specifications were explicitly assigned to the interface, it “inherits” the specifications of its microservice.

If the service also exhibited no protocol specifications and thus the interface does neither, code generators should produce sensible defaults, e.g., from the interface’s name.

IntermediateOperation[*] operations

Operations of the interface.

IntermediateReferredOperation[*] referredOperations

Referred Operations of the interface.

Note

An interface defines at least one operation or refers to an existing operation, i.e., at least one of the operations and referredOperations is not empty.

IntermediateImportedAspect[*] aspects

Aspects of the interface.

IntermediateMicroservice microservice

Link to the containing IntermediateMicroservice instance.

class IntermediateOperation¶

This class represents an operation of an IntermediateInterface.

String[1] name

Name of the operation.

String[1] qualifiedName

Qualified name of the operation. This is the operation’s name prefixed by its interface’s qualified name. Both name fragments are separated by dots.

Visibility[1] visibility

Visibility of the operation.

boolean notImplemented

Flag to indicate if the operation was marked as being not implemented.

Hint

Code generators should consider to also generate code for not (yet) implemented operation and, e.g., return failures to callers.

IntermediateEndpoint[*] endpoints

Endpoints assigned to the operation.

Hint

If no endpoints were specified for the operation’s (default) protocol specifications, the addresses attribute of the IntermediateEndpoint class will be empty.

If no endpoints were specified or could be determined from (default) protocol specifications, or in case the addresses attribute is empty, code generators should produce sensible defaults, e.g., from the operation’s name.

IntermediateProtocolSpecification[0..2] protocols

Protocol specifications assigned to the operation. There might be exactly one protocol specification per communication type.

Hint

If no protocol specifications were explicitly assigned to the operation, it “inherits” the specifications of its interface.

If the interface also exhibited no protocol specifications and thus the operation does neither, code generators should produce sensible defaults, e.g., from the operation’s name.

IntermediateParameter[*] parameters

Parameters of the operation.

Note

There might be more than one outgoing parameter and it is up to code generators on how to proceed with this. For example, all outgoing parameters could be condensed within a uniforming data structure.

IntermediateApiOperationComment[0..1] apiOperationComment

API comment of the operation.

IntermediateImportedAspect[*] aspects

Aspects of the operation.

IntermediateInterface interface

Link to the containing IntermediateInterface instance.

class IntermediateApiOperationComment¶

An API-related comment of an operation. It describes the purpose of the operation, possibly together with its parameters in IntermediateApiParameterComment instances.

String[1] comment

Comment, which describes the operation.

IntermediateApiParameterComment[*] parameterComments

API comments for the operation’s parameters.

Hint

It is possible that a parameter is commented more than once. Code generators are free in their reaction to such a situation. For instance, all comments may be dropped except for the last one or they may ask users on how to proceed in such a situation.

IntermediateOperation operation

The operation being documented by this comment.

class IntermediateApiParameterComment¶

An API-related comment for a parameter of an operation.

String[1] comment

Comment, which describes the parameter.

boolean required

Flag to indicate if this parameter is required (from an API point of view).

Note

It is possible to document even optional parameters as being required.

IntermediateParameter parameter

The parameter being documented by this comment.

IntermediateApiOperationComment operationComment

The API operation comment to which this parameter comment belongs.

class IntermediateParameter¶

A parameter of an operation.

String[1] name

Name of the parameter.

String[1] qualifiedName

Qualified name of the parameter. This is the parameter’s name prefixed by its operation’s qualified name. Both name fragments are separated by dots.

ExchangePattern[1] exchangePattern

ExchangePattern of the parameter.

CommunicationType[1] communicationType

CommunicationType of the parameter.

boolean communicatesFault

Flag to indicate that the parameter is used to communicate fault values to the caller.

Note

It is up to the code generator to ensure that the caller is aware that the parameter communicates a fault.

boolean optional

Flag to indicate that the parameter is optional.

Note

The combination of the exchangePattern, communicationType, and optional attributes determine a parameter’s “timing behavior”:

Exchange Pattern Communication Type Opt? Operation Behavior
IN ASYNCHRONOUS false Operation may retrieve value at an arbitrary point in time during its execution.
IN ASYNCHRONOUS true Operation must retrieve value at some point in time during its execution.
IN SYNCHRONOUS false Operation can only be executed if parameter has has a value.
IN SYNCHRONOUS true Operation can be executed without the parameter value and it cannot expect to ever retrieve a value for the parameter.
OUT ASYNCHRONOUS false Operation may emit value at an arbitrary point in time during its execution.
OUT ASYNCHRONOUS true Operation emits value at some point in time during its execution.
OUT SYNCHRONOUS false Operation emits value when it finished its execution.
OUT SYNCHRONOUS true Operation might emit value after it finished its execution.
INOUT all all Parameter behaves like an incoming and outgoing parameter for the respective communication type and “optional” flag.
IntermediateType type

Type of the parameter.

Note

A parameter cannot be typed with the built-in primitive type unspecified.

OperationReference initializedByOperation

Link to the IntermediateOperation that initializes the parameter.

Note

It is not safely guaranteed that the operation’s return values and the parameter’s type are compatible. This is due to the Service Modeling Language only yielding a warning if a (possible) type incompatibility is detected. Moreover, the type check is based on the type system of the Domain Data Modeling Language, which may not be applicable to all target languages.

IntermediateImportedAspect[*] aspects

Aspects of the parameter.

DataFieldAspects[*] fieldAspects

Aspects that were assigned to fields of the structure type or enumeration type of the parameter within a Mapping Model.

Hint

These aspects are relevant only in the context of the parameter within its defining operation. They are, however, not relevant in the context of the type of that defines the fields in its Data Model. Aspects that were assigned to fields of the complex type itself are directly assigned to the type in the corresponding IntermediateDataModel.

IntermediateOperation operation

Link to the containing IntermediateOperation instance.

class DataFieldAspects¶

This concepts contains aspects that were assigned to fields of a parameter's structure type or enumeration type within a Mapping Model.

String[1] name

The name of the structure type’s or enumeration type’s field to which the aspects in the context of the parameter were assigned.

String[1] qualifiedName

Qualified name of the field. It consists of the field’s name prefixed by the parameter’s qualified name.

IntermediateImportedAspect[1..*] aspects

The aspects that were assigned to the field in the context of the parameter.

IntermediateParameter parameter

Link to the containing IntermediateParameter instance.

class IntermediateReferredOperation¶

Referred operation of an IntermediateInterface. In contrast to IntermediateOperations, referred operations do not implement their own business logic. Instead, they act as façades to implemented IntermediateOperations within the same microservice. That is, requests/responses to the original operation/the caller are just forwarded by referred operations.

Referred operations exhibit the same parameters as the original operations. However, they may have different endpoints, protocols, and aspects.

String[1] nameInReferringInterface

The name of the referred operation within the referring interface. Currently, the name is identical to the name of the original operation. However, code generators should not rely on that and instead use the content of this attribute to generate the referring operation.

String[1] qualifiedNameInReferringInterface

The qualified name of the referred operation within the referring interface. It consists of the name of the referring operation prefixed by the qualified name of its interface. Both name fragments are separated by dots.

IntermediateOperation[1] operation

Link to the original operation.

Note

The type of the attribute is IntermediateOperation instead of OperationReference, because the original operation must be in the same microservice as the referring operation and can thus not originate from an imported Service Model.

IntermediateEndpoint[*] endpoints

Endpoints assigned to the referred operation.

Hint

If no endpoints were specified for the referred operation’s (default) protocol specifications, the addresses attribute of the IntermediateEndpoint class will be empty.

If no endpoints were specified or could be determined from (default) protocol specifications, or in case the addresses attribute is empty, code generators should produce sensible defaults, e.g., from the referred operation’s name.

IntermediateProtocolSpecification[0..2] protocols

Protocol specifications assigned to the referred operation. There might be exactly one protocol specification per communication type.

Hint

If no protocol specifications were explicitly assigned to the referred operation, it “inherits” the specifications of its interface.

If the interface also exhibited no protocol specifications and thus the referred operation does neither, code generators should produce sensible defaults, e.g., from the referred operation’s name.

IntermediateImportedAspect[*] aspects

Aspects of the referred operation.

IntermediateInterface referringInterface

Link to the containing IntermediateInterface instance.

3.3   Communication¶

This subsection describes concepts related to specifying the communication between microservices.

enum CommunicationType¶

The values of this enum represent certain communication types.

enumerator ASYNCHRONOUS¶

Asynchronous communication.

enumerator SYNCHRONOUS¶

Synchronous communication.

enum ExchangePattern¶

The values of this enum represent certain exchange patterns.

enumerator IN¶

Incoming information exchange.

enumerator OUT¶

Outgoing information exchange.

enumerator INOUT¶

Incoming and outgoing information exchange.

class IntermediateEndpoint¶

A protocol- and format-specific endpoint, e.g., “http://www.example.org” for HTTP and a format like JSON.

CommunicationType[1] communicationType

The communication type assigned to the endpoint. It corresponds to the communication type of the endpoint’s protocol.

String[1] protocol

Name of the endpoint’s protocol.

String[1] dataFormat

Name of the endpoint’s data format.

String[*] addresses

List of protocol- and format-specific addresses that were assigned to the endpoint, e.g., “http://www.example.org”.

Hint

If the list of addresses is empty, code generators should produce sensible defaults, as described here, here, here, and here.

Hint

In case the modeler did not specify a data format for an endpoint, it depends on the technology models, which endpoints are created. If the technology model defines a default protocol and thus a default format, an endpoint for this protocol and format is created. If the protocol is not the default protocol for the communication type and hence does not define a default format, endpoints for all formats of the protocols are created. However, code generators must only produce endpoints for the protocols and data formats that were assigned to the respective microservice, interface, operation, or referred operation.

Hint

The addresses are not checked for validity by the Service Modeling Language. This step has to be done by model processors.

IntermediateTechnology[1] technology

Link to the Technology Model (cf. Table 1) which defines the protocol and data format.

IntermediateMicroservice microservice

IntermediateMicroservice to which the endpoint was assigned.

IntermediateInterface interface

IntermediateInterface to which the endpoint was assigned.

IntermediateOperation operation

IntermediateOperation to which the endpoint was assigned.

IntermediateReferredOperation referredOperation

IntermediateReferredOperation to which the endpoint was assigned.

class IntermediateProtocolSpecification¶

A protocol and data format specification.

CommunicationType[1] communicationType

CommunicationType of the specification.

String[1] protocol

Name of the specification’s protocol.

String[1] dataFormat

Name of the specification’s data format.

3.4   References¶

This subsection describes concepts that are used to model references to possibly imported microservices, interfaces, or operation.

class MicroserviceReference¶

Reference to a possibly imported microservice.

String[1] name

Name of the referenced microservice.

String version

Version of the referenced microservice.

String[1] qualifiedName

Qualified name of the referenced microservice.

boolean imported

Flag to indicate if the referenced microservice was imported from another Service Model.

IntermediateImport import

Link to the IntermediateImport which points to the imported Service Model. If the imported flag is true this attribute contains a value. Otherwise it is null.

IntermediateMicroservice localMicroservice

Link to the referenced IntermediateMicroservice in the same Service Model as the MicroserviceReference. If the imported flag is true this attribute is null. Otherwise it contains a value.

Hint

If the attribute is null, i.e., the referenced microservice is defined in another Service Model, model processors need to retrieve details of the referenced service from the imported Service Model themselves. That is, they need to parse the imported model and find the referenced microservice leveraging the qualified name of this MicroserviceReference instance.

IntermediateMicroservice requiringMicroservice

IntermediateMicroservice that requires this microservice.

class InterfaceReference¶

Reference to a possibly imported interface.

String[1] name

Name of the referenced interface.

String version

Version of the referenced interface.

String[1] qualifiedName

Qualified name of the referenced interface.

boolean imported

Flag to indicate if the referenced interface was imported from another Service Model.

IntermediateImport import

Link to the IntermediateImport which points to the imported Service Model. If the imported flag is true this attribute contains a value. Otherwise it is null.

IntermediateInterface localInterface

Link to the referenced IntermediateInterface in the same Service Model as the InterfaceReference. If the imported flag is true this attribute is null. Otherwise it contains a value.

Hint

If the attribute is null, i.e., the referenced interface is defined in another Service Model, model processors need to retrieve details of the referenced interface from the imported Service Model themselves. That is, they need to parse the imported model and find the referenced interface leveraging the qualified name of this InterfaceReference instance.

IntermediateMicroservice requiringMicroservice

IntermediateMicroservice that requires this interface.

class OperationReference¶

Reference to a possibly imported operation.

String[1] name

Name of the referenced operation.

String[1] qualifiedName

Qualified name of the referenced operation.

boolean imported

Flag to indicate if the referenced operation was imported from another Service Model.

IntermediateImport import

Link to the IntermediateImport which points to the imported Service Model. If the imported flag is true this attribute contains a value. Otherwise it is null.

IntermediateOperation localOperation

Link to the referenced IntermediateOperation in the same Service Model as the OperationReference. If the imported flag is true this attribute is null. Otherwise it contains a value.

Hint

If the attribute is null, i.e., the referenced operation is defined in another Service Model, model processors need to retrieve details of the referenced operation from the imported Service Model themselves. That is, they need to parse the imported model and find the referenced operation leveraging the qualified name of this OperationReference instance.

IntermediateMicroservice requiringMicroservice

IntermediateMicroservice that requires this operation.

IntermediateParameter initializedParameter

IntermediateParameter that is initialized by this operation.
